question: Question_01_(e)
sols:
A function $f$ has an inverse if and only if it is \emph{bijective}. That
is, it has an inverse if and only if it is

\begin{enumerate}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  Injective (or one-to-one)
\item
  Surjective (or onto).
\end{enumerate}

In such a case, for every \emph{y} ∈ \emph{B}, there is a unique
\emph{x} ∈ \emph{A} such that $f(x)$ = \emph{y}. Using this fact,
we define $f$\textsuperscript{-1} by the rule

\[\displaystyle
f^{-1}(y) = x\]

where \emph{x} is the unique element of the set \emph{A} such that
$f(x)$ = \emph{y}. From the injectivity and surjectivity, this is
well defined. Moreover,

\[f\big(f^{-1}(y)\big) = f(x) = y\]

and

\[f^{-1}\big(f(x)\big) = f^{-1}(y) = x\]

and so this really is the inverse of $f$.
hints:
Why doesn't the function

\begin{align*}
f : \{0,1\} &\to \{3\}\\
0 &\mapsto 3\\
1 &\mapsto 3
\end{align*} have an inverse?

What about the function

\begin{align*}
g: \{0\} &\to \{1,2\}\\
0 &\mapsto 2
\end{align*}
